description:
The new Nvidia RTX 5090 delivers the fastest gaming performance ever seen from a consumer GPU - but at an average 31 percent improvement over RTX 4090, is that enough to meet expectations? And meanwhile, what about DLSS 4? Are frame generation fps boosts actually increased performance? It's tricky - and the discussion has only just begun.

Eurogamer web review with all of our numbers: https://www.eurogamer.net/digitalfoundry-2025-nvidia-geforce-rtx-5090-review

Want some DF-branded tee-shirts, mugs, hoodies and various items based on DF catchphrases? Check out our store: https://store.digitalfoundry.net

Join the DF Supporter Program for pristine video downloads, behind the scenes content, early access to DF Retro, early access to DF Direct Weekly and much, much more: https://bit.ly/3jEGjvx

Subscribe for more Digital Foundry: http://bit.ly/DFSubscribe

comments.text:
I honestly hate all of this. As much as these frame rate boosts are interesting from an experimental perspective, I find them completely and utterly useless. The only point to increasing frame rate is improving latency, and this does the opposite. These technologies also won't allow the GPU to do more things per real frame, which means gameplay graphics will stall in exchange for fake frames that have no benefit whatsoever. I just don't get the point. And if you're already achieving a high frame rate before framegen, then it already looks good, and I'd MUCH prefer native frame rate than an artificially boosted one with increased latency.

But a GPU doing more per real frame is much more important than any of this garbage.

comments.text: One of the biggest disappointments about RTX 50 is that it didn't get a proper process node upgrade. RTX 50 has to rely mostly on architectural enhancements for performance gains. There's only so much performance that can be extracted from architectural enhancements. TSMC 3nm die sizes are roughly 45% smaller than TSMC 5nm. That would have allowed for substantial enhancements for Blackwell's silicon. This is not even referring to more enhanced 3nm nodes such as N3P, N3X, and a custom 3N process node, which will further boost the performance and transistor density. TSMC 3nm, especially a custom 3N process node, would have been a huge upgrade over the custom 4N process node that RTX 40 uses. Back when RTX 50 was rumoured to use a custom TSMC 3N process node, the leaked specs were much beefier as the SM count and clock speeds were way higher. The 50 Series would have been a heck of a lot faster if they had used a custom TSMC 3N process node. They also would have been more power efficient.

comments.text:
I think the narrative "AMD chose not to challenge Nvidia at the top end" needs to be addressed. This was true in the 7000/4000 series. Their 7900 XTX was competitive with the 4080/Super, they chose not to compete with the 4090 (which I think was a reasonable decision). This time they are not competing with the 5090, but they are also not competing with the 5080, or 5070. In fact they are not even competing with the 7900 XTX, their slide shows that this is still going to be their most performant part. This means that their next gen product, based on AMD's slide, is barely even going to compete with the 4070, let alone anything of the same gen. They are choosing not to challenge Nvidia at the top end. They are also choosing not to challenge them at the high end, and also a lot of the middle.

Personally the only logical conclusion I can see is that while AMD and Intel are squabbling over the low end budget market, the literal lack of any other competing option for the vast majority of the product stack is going to push Nvidia's market share over 90%, meanwhile all of the usual whining at gamers "you idiots always complain about the prices of graphics cards, and then go and buy your Nvidia" will continue despite there literally being no other option since AMD handed Nvidia their monopoly.
comments.author: @cakeisamadeupdrug6134

comments.text:

The fans required to keep this monster cool is just too loud, or too expensive - especially after you've already dropped US$2,000.

For the 60-series, I would happily take a very modicum improvement in performance, if it meant it was half the size, half the wattage, half as hot, and half as loud. Then by the time they repeat that again for the 70-series - 150W is still too much, but at least my room won't turn into an oven - it might be worth buying then.

comments.text: @ChrisDaytrader  if DF are just taking the "frame rate" with multi frame generation and dividing 1 second by this then the latency will look better I guess? comments.text:
strongly disagree with the x4 frame gen, the amount of artifacts you get makes the games look very bad in anything that is moving a little bit fast (even worst on stuff like hair, transparency etc.). The lag input cost of the technology is also an issue. This technology is only "usefull" if you are arleady past 90 FPS without FG. When you see the difference in image quality, I'll chose to stay at 90 fps low latency anytime. DLSS is a fantastic technology, especially the version 4, a lot of artifacts and precedent issue have been solved. But Frame gen is a gimmick in my eyes so the  marketing department can say without any shame or law suit risk: X times the performance from previous generation.

If you try to use frame gen when you are around 50-60 fps (where you would want a technology like that), you will feel the massive cost in lag input to get 120 or 200+.

comments.text:
How many people have 400hz monitors or monitors that can support more than 400hz at 4K?
A lot of people would effectively be throwing their money away. 5090, even for most elitist PC gamer types, would still be like throwing money directly into a fireplace. What's worse is that as PC game devs start targeting 5000 series, everyone will see GPU performance fall off a cliff.

I mean, a lot of people claimed there's effectively no visual differences between R&C on PS4 Pro and R&C on a base PS5, but the fact that my PC GPU has no difficulties running 3rd party PS4 Xbox One era games at 4K60 maxed-out, but has serious difficulties running R&C:RA in 900p at 30FPS with the lowest settings on a the maximum tier Gen 3 NVMe drive my PC motherboard supports, which shows there is some kind of difference beyond what people see and what is being rendered.

Besides the obvious visual differences that I noticed instantly in YT trailers, like improved lighting, higher quality shaders, more shaders, more dynamic objects, a doubling of rendering resolution, and framerate plus RT, which my PC doesn't even support due to lack of support rather than lack of power.

Consider that some current generation retail PC releases, like FH5, hit 1440p30 maxed with RT on the same PC that struggles to run R&C:RA at 900p30 with minimum settings without RT. There is still quite a bit of raster umph behind the GTX 1000 series that is being brushed aside today. Devs might treat RTX 5000 as the start of a new era for PC. The neural or AI era is effectively starting, and the fact that PS5 Pro and mobile game ready devices down to smartphones are also leveraging ML makes this almost a certainty.

comments.text:
This is the thing. All Products come to an end point. Capitalist may try to make you believe you can get a 30% profit increase every year, but that is literally impossible with technological progress/the limits of physics. GPU's and silicon will eventually get to the point where performance jumps are minimal and graphic increases will hit a wall. It's why I don't exactly care about AI since that is the future of rendering. The issue is that the industry, wanting to always gain those profits, jumped onto AI to quickly for the perceived time cost reductions on their end. We as the players are now having to take the brunt of their actions, with developers not knowing how to optimise RT or UE5 for their games in a transitional period. While GPU prices to impliment this technology have skyrocketed.

A personal suggestion to players out there. Don't buy a new GPU until prices come down in the future due to the raster wall being hit/Nvidia's stock price tumbles when AI hit's it too. There are tons of games you can play without RT, MMO's that provide infinite content or even emulation. If you buy now, your only investing in prototype technology that hasn't been fully understood on the developer end yet. This might change in the next 5-10years or so.

comments.text: 4:26 This is the most important aspect for buyers to understand. Way too many people that do not come from hardware engineering backgrounds fail to understand just how expensive it would be to develop hardware that would create the same kind of gains we are seeing on the software side. That doesnt even factor in the power, cooling, and size requirements. Everyone is screaming "hurr fake frames" but would be the first ones to hate on GPU makers if they made a GPU that relied solely on native performance. Those kind of GPUs would be massive (for cooling needs), have outrageous power requirements, and would be insanely more expensive than whats on the market now. Software is always going to be cheaper to develop and leverage. Im personally fine with with engineers leveraging software solutions for performance gains and that is exactly what Nvidia is doing here.

comments.text:
I'm struggling to get my head around the new PC latency metric, vs traditional frame time. eg 21:53. To keep it simple, with MFG off: DLSS Perf super res hits 102fps, and as I understand it that is 9.8ms frame time (1000 / fps = frame time) which the graph at the bottom supports. But for the latency to be 24.2ms, why is that higher than frame time when MFG is off? Is this factoring in input lag from keyboard/mouse? Or adding in pixel response times on the display? What part of the input to display chain is being added that causes latency to be higher than frame time?

That said once MFG is enabled and as it steps up, it makes sense why latency will be increasing as it will depend on traditionally rendered frames, for which rendering is slowing down slightly, and why frame time is going down because of all those AI generated interstitial frames

Hi Rich, as others have about the audio. I like that you upgraded (I did suggest previously a youtuber of your size should not be using a blue yeti but a shure sm7b or re20 the one I use). These dynamic mics are designed the reject background noise which is why I suspect you had to turn the gain very high to get the right volume and also why the audio sounds distorted.

People generally speak very close to this mic as they feature something called proximity effect (that classic radio sound) - it's up to how how close. Also these mics are used in podcasting and radio stations, I would also suggest you get your audio nerds to do some eq and compression. It can be done with software, but hardware is better. But I can tell the mic is gonna sound amazing once you set it up properly.

comments.text:
The theoretical best latency with traditional rendering should be the reciprocal of the fps. Frame gen requires 2 frames. So the best possible latency is 2 times the latency of traditional rendering. 

So at 120 fps with 2x frame gen, you have 60 traditional frames. Which gives a latency of 16.6ms, or 33.3ms of latency since we have frame gen enabled.

But the latencies we are seeing appear to be completely disconnected from the frame rate. What is causing the inputs to be delayed by several frames? 

The latencies are always larger than I would expect. And the measured latencies don't align with the way it feels. Otherwise the latency should feel better, according to the provided numbers here. But it feels delayed when I actually use it. 

Is the latency being measured wrong?

I'm confused...
In "Alan Wake 2" the "x2" Frame Gen results are almost 2x as great. Let's call it 120FPS vs 60FPS for simplicity. When it's at "120FPS" then you interpolate every 2nd frame. So you wait 1/60th second for every new, real frame. BUT... you should be adding a full FRAME of LATENCY shouldn't you? You have to WAIT for a 2nd frame before you can interpolate, then show the intermediary frame... so...
At 60FPS that's 16.7ms per frame.
Then how is there only 8ms or so average difference between 60FPS native and 120FPS with frame gen?
Shouldn't it be closer to 20ms?
What don't I get?

comments.text: This is why we love Digital Foundry. In-depth, no nonsense, unbiased view of the data presented. There's clearly not as high a raw rasterization performance uplift as some people had hoped for. But on the other hand, this proves Nvidia was right about the new MFG. As all things in life, the truth always lies somewhere in the middle between the extreme optimisim and extreme pessimism. I could care less that the 5090 is only 30% on average better at rasterization than the 4090. Why? Because I don't own a 4090. I own a 3080. So when I now decide to get a 5090, 5 years after my last GPU buy, I'm going to get a 250% performance increase at 4K WITHOUT MFG. I honestly wonder why people always look at this products thinking everyone is out here looking to spend 1600-2500 every 2 years on a single hardware component. People already say you shouldn't replace your phone every year. Why is this any different here? 2 generations on a GPU upgrade cycle is and always has been, one of the more sensible decisions one can make. Could I have bought a 4090? Absolutely. But I didn't want to. And it turns out, I was right, for my use-case. The MFG is exactly what I want and need, as actually taking advantage of my 4K 240hz monitor is not doable currently in rasterization, with any GPU, period. These questions always need to be looked at from a position of context. That's how you make value judgements. Not frames per dollar. Frames per dollar is a stupid metric, because no one buys GPUs like that. They buy with their own wallets and what they can afford, and more importantly, are WILLING to spend on that hardware. Everyone is different. For my case, the 5090 looks like a great choice. BUT, the MFG info, also indicates that the 5080 may be an even greater choice for my perspective of value. The question then becomes, what's the real world price going to end up at? And do I need the 5090 (now and in the next 2 gpu gen cycle)?

comments.text:
I don’t know if I missed something, but in the DLSS 4 section, why are we seeing MFG with DLSS set to Performance compared to native resolution first, and then DLSS Performance vs DLSS Performance + MFG? Isn’t the whole point of Frame Generation to maintain smoother frame rates without compromising resolution or visuals?

Wouldn’t it have made more sense to show MFG paired with DLSS Quality compared to native or DLSS Performance, so we can better assess the visual and latency trade-offs? Using DLSS Performance + MFG feels like overkill since the resolution is already significantly reduced, and you’re adding more input latency for potentially worse visuals than just using DLSS Super Resolution without FG. Maybe this will be addressed in Alex’s analysis, but I would’ve liked to see how little I would need to compromise in terms of resolution and visuals in order to achieve a decent frame rate. Yeah, I get that when the base frame rate is already low and latency is high, adding MFG would make latency worse. But I can’t imagine it can be much worse than playing at 60 (or even 30) fps without FG, which is what most people on console are used to anyway. Lol.

Because the frame rate of 30fps is too low. The longer it takes to push frames to the display, the higher the latency. 

Which kinda strikes at the heart of this card's strengths. If you want to run a cutting edge game with full path tracing and ulatra settings at 4k, without DLSS, your latency is gonna be through the roof due to the low fps. At that point, the only argument you can really make against leaving DLSS off is that the graphical quality isn't as pristine, since the latency is now going to be better than native. Nvidia's 5000 series is just overclocked 4000 series.

4090 is 76% faster than 3090.

@nuruddinpeters9491  I think they are on a slightly different process actually. RTX 4000 is on 4N and RTX 5000 is on N4P. N4P has a 6% performance improvement over N4, though I couldn't find how similar 4N is to N4, so I don't know the exact performance improvement of N4P over 4N, but it's probably not a very large improvement, which would explain why Nvidia had to up the power draw to increase performance as much as they did.
As far as RTX 6000 is concerned, assuming it runs on the Rubin architecture it will probably use a 3nm class node, but I'm not sure which 3nm node it will use. This is what I read on the Rubin architecture page on Wikipedia, anyway. Who knows what the pricing on 3nm will be in 2 years though, which will determine how RTX 6000 GPUs are marketed and priced. I wouldn't be surprised if the days of 50%+ rasterization performance improvements per generation are over, so hopefully the kinks in AI tech are ironed out over the next few generations.

OK. To be clear. Is the latency displayed calculated based on a per real frame or is it calculated based on a per total frames sent to the screen (1 real + 3 smoothed).
Because it makes a big difference.

"The game doesn't feel any better to play" implies that the latency depends only on rasterized (real) frames which means if you're getting something like 30 fps but 100 smoothed the real game experience is massively downgraded. So we're back to the same issue we had with first gen frame generation. It doesn't matter unless you've got extremely high framerate and if you've got extremely high framerate you're likely playing competitive which means you can't afford the extra ~33% latency increase.

If feels at this point that it's a feature for the ppl complaining that they went to a high refresh rate monitor and they get a tinge if they go back to 60. In other words, spending money to spend more money but not achieving any real improvement in experience.

comments.author: @icefox1983

comments.text: @MrPloopy83  what's noticeable isn't the 10+ms FG latency, but the overall latency. A game needs to have sub 70ms latency or so to feel acceptable and sub 50ms latency to feel good. Native 30fps already has a 60-70ms system latency. Adding 10ms and it will feel terrible. You need to budget 10ms for FG in the 60ms system latency, and you are left with 50ms for native rendering, that's about 40-50 native fps, hence the suggestion that FG be utilized only for 40+ native fps.

comments.text:
From what I've read, RTX 4000 is built on TSMC N4 while RTX 5000 is built on TSMC N4P. They are very similar but N4P has a 6%  performance improvement over N4 according to an article from AnandTech. While N4P is still considered a "5nm" node it still has efficiency and power improvements over N5 (11% increase in performance or 22% decrease in power usage according to AnandTech). Of course, like @SimonBuchanNz pointed out, 5nm is just a marketing term now and nothing about the transistors is actually 5 nanometers anymore. 

That being said, the gist of what you are saying is still correct. Transistor improvements in GPUs are slowing down because of the increasing cost and complexity of making better and smaller transistors. 

My prediction is that even when Nvidia moves to a 3nm class node, we're still not going to see the same price to performance improvements we've seen in years past as far as rasterization is concerned. Hopefully the issues with AI upscalling and framegen latency get ironed out within the next few GPU generations because I don't think computer chip hardware is going to continue to improve at the same rate and in the same way it has been for the past 50 years.

Correction: RTX 4000 series is based on 4N, not N4. I don't know what the difference in performance is between the two, but I would imagine that N4P still has slightly better performance.

comments.text: While there are latency penalties for MCM due to there being more than a single chip to communicate with. Once they figure out how to get MCM gaming GPUs working properly, maybe with hyper-speed bus links to interconnect the SMs (Nvidia), CUs (AMD), EUs (Intel), and super-fast infinity fabric to massively reduce die-to-die latency, it will be a total game changer. With MCM GPUs, they will be able to pack way more hardware and processing power into a big chip. MCM has several benefits as well, such as cheaper manufacturing costs, higher yield rates, high scalability, and being highly power efficient. Because with MCM, multiple smaller chiplets are combined together to make one large chip. This often works out to be substantially cheaper than a monolithic chip, which is just one big chip, because smaller chips have a much higher yield rate, are cheaper to produce, and have a much lower chance of any defects happening. All these benefits that MCM offers can result in huge cost savings. This is why once the limit is reached by how many transistors can be packed into a monolithic chip, MCM will become the standard and be the future of gaming GPUs.

comments.text: @igorrafael7429  You have very high standards. Given how frame generation works, its impossible to not introduce additional latency. Frame generation is different then the standard rendering of frames. For example, lets look at 2 individual frames. Both frames are rendered by your graphics card. Frame generation will generate a frame that goes between those two frames, creating smoother on-screen movement without the additional stress on your gpu. However, to do this, the frames will have to be held momentarily while the generated frame is created. That is where the latency is introduced.  So, to me and a lot of other nerds, its very impressive that they have been able to get the latency as low as they have considering what all is happening in only ~30 milliseconds of time.

comments.text:
​ @oropher1234 You are conflating fps and latency. It's not that uncommon for people to game at 100ms latencies on consoles going through an AVR and a TV. Unless you're playing a rhythm game, MOBA, competitive shooter etc., your brain actually handles predictable lag quite easily.

This is because brains have their own signal processing delay and, as such, actually predict up to several hundred Ms into the future to produce what you "see" so you're able to react faster.

Now, 100ms+ systems aren't for me, but a stable bump from 30ms to 40ms of latency is a change I wouldn't expect anyone to notice in practice in a blind A/B test.

One of the hardest tricks in speed running is hitting frame-perfect inputs at 60fps. These are extremely difficult to time for people who spend thousands of hours practicing, and that window is almost double the latency being added.

Maybe you're the rare exception that would notice this difference. But what I see from your comment is that when the frame rate increases, you don't have a good sense of the extent to which it is latency vs fluidity that is improving your experience.

Because if you think 240fps/40ms feels like 40fps (or however your math was supposed to work), that just proves you've never seen it.

comments.text:
Yep I miss the good old days when we got real progress for the money, where basically, you get 30% more performance for the same price as the last gen, now it feels like we are paying a higher price for progress in the gpu sector, which is a stark contest to what we are seeing in the cpu sector.

So it's progress but not really progress if you're paying almost the same amount higher as a percentage for the performance gains you get, which for me isn't tech progress, real progress is getting more performance gen on gen for around the same price point or lower as the last gen, what we are seeing from Nvidia isn't really progress when you're paying almost the same percentage amount for that progress, and I do wonder, at this rate, the 8060 gen of gpu's is going to cost around $7-8-00 if this keeps going on, especially as Nvidia wants to keep pushing the tiers up the price bracket.

In any case, clearly AMD isn't going to change anything, they've got good enough gpu's for most consumers, but the pricing isn't aggressive enough, Intel isn't quite ready yet to shake things up, I have a feeling that over the next 5 years, ARM's players could really shake up the PC market when it comes to performance and price, especially as they are outsiders to the PC market and will likely be more aggressive on pricing to shake up the PC market and steal market share from AMD, Nvidia and Intel, which the high price and greed of AMD, Nvidia and Intel are making them an easy target for new competition.
